£
Employee added years

Before the introduction of Additional pension (AP), members could buy Added years to increase their NHS pension benefits at retirement. This involves the member paying extra contributions every month. The amount is set as a fixed percentage of their pensionable pay. This extra contribution is on top of their basic tiered employee contributions.

It is no longer possible to make a new application to buy full cost Added years. However, an existing contract remains active until completed, which is at age 55, 60, or 65. This means that employers with staff who currently buy Added years, must collect the extra contributions and forward them to NHS Pensions within the 19 day deadline.

Employers need to be aware that:

  • employees who were subject to the HMRC earnings cap also have capped Added years contributions
  • if a member has a break in Scheme membership of 12 months or more, the Added years contract ceases and extra contributions must also stop
£
Additional pension

Additional pension (AP) replaced the full cost Added years arrangement in April 2008. Members can buy units of £250 to increase their annual NHS Pension. Limits are set for a maximum career increase of £5,000 in the 1995/2008 Scheme and £6,500 in the 2015 Scheme.

These limits operate independently. This means a member who bought AP whilst a member of the 1995/2008 Scheme, is also able to buy up to an additional £6,500 annual pension after moving to the 2015 Scheme.

It is possible to buy AP in instalments or as a one-off payment. Employers are legally responsible for collecting contributions and sending them to NHS Pensions at the same time as employee and employer contributions.

AP contributions attract tax relief within limits set by HM Revenue and Customs.

£
What is ERRBO?​

2015 Scheme members have the ability to buy out the reduction that would apply if claiming retirement benefits before normal pension age. In the 2015 Scheme this is the same as the member’s State Pension Age, or age 65 if later.

This may rise during membership of the Scheme if state pension age rises.
